body: The police said yesterday that a ''failure of communication'' between officers investigating the death of Michael Griffith had caused several hours of confusion over what car killed him after he was chased and beaten in the Howard Beach racial assault. The concession of the procedural error was the latest of several revisions, additions and
title: POLICE CONCEDE COMMUNICATION FAILURE

body: Detectives investigating the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, reported new details yesterday that they said showed that the motorist whose car killed the victim was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder. The investigators recounted the actions of the motorist, Dominick Blum, on the night of Dec. 19-20 when Michael
title: NEW DETAILS GIVEN IN QUEENS ATTACK

body: The death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, in what is widely perceived as the worst racial incident in New York City in years has, after more than a week of intense scrutiny, left a host of unanswered questions. Some facts are not in dispute: a group of white youths at a party, hearing that three blacks were walking through their community,
title: THE HOWARD BEACH INQUIRY: MANY KEY QUESTIONS PERSIST

body: The police said yesterday that their investigation of the accident in Howard Beach, Queens, that killed Michael Griffith indicated that the motorist who struck him was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder. In doing so, they contradicted a lawyer for one of the two other blacks who were victims of the attacks that preceeded
title: POLICE INQUIRY INTO MOTORIST CONTRADICTS LAWYER'S STAND

body: THE three-story brownstone at 110 Hart Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn is little more than a shell, a sagging husk without heat, hot water or toilets. Three families live there using buckets for plumbing. They heat themselves with barbecue charcoal. They light their grim rooms with pirated electricity carried by a web of
title: New York Plays Reluctant Landlord

title: SUCCESS OF BROOKLYN ACADEMY STRAINS RELATIONS WITH HOTLE FOR HOMELESS

body: A suspect in as many as 16 Brooklyn rape cases was arrested Thursday night after a victim identified him at a subway stakeout, the police said. The
title: SUSPECT IN A SERIES OF RAPES ISEIZED AT BMT STAKEOUT

body: Ten people - a family of five in Plainview, L.I., and a family of five living above a storefront church in Brooklyn - were killed in early morning fires yesterday. title: TWO FAMILIES PERISH IN FIRES AT HOME IN BROOKLYN AND NASSAU

body: The Koch administration plans for the first time to sell large clusters of abandoned apartment buildings it owns in a single neighborhood. But the plan has run into stiff opposition from community and housing groups, which say it will divide the neighborhood economically and racially. Usually, the city individually sells the buildings that it
title: CITY SELLING PROSPECT HEIGHTS PARCELS

body: A COUPLE of years ago, on a travel-writing assignment in Kenya, I had Thanksgiving dinner at a table for one at the Mount Kenya Safari Club. The food was delicious, but I had to clear lumps in my throat a few times. My husband was home in New York and my children were scattered, but it wasn't missing them that made me feel sad. I was musing about
title: WESTCHESTER OPINION; NORMAN ROCKWELL RARELY SAT AT MY TABLE

title: New York Agenda

body: THE scene: A group of high-powered executives assembles for a meeting. One of them looks out the window and notices something strange going on in the parking lot. Some ''hotshots from finance'' are carrying computers from their cars into the building. Does the company allow employees to take its computers home, an executive asks. No, he is told.
title: ADS WITH THE DUSENBERRY TOUCH

body: Fare Cards on WayNew York City's Transit Authority is allowing plenty of time to iron out any wrinkles as it cautiously introduces a laminated polyester fare card for the subways. title: COLUMN ONE: TRANSPORT; A Subway Advance and a Cabby Protest

body: It is over the bridge or through the tunnel, but in some ways Brooklyn is more entitled than Manhattan to call itself the heart of New York. This is, after all, the borough more New Yorkers live in than any other; it stretches from the gracious brownstones of the Heights to the sprawling slabs of Starrett City, and in between are neighborhoods of
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; A Borough Filled With Brilliant Gems of Urban Architecture

body: Manhattanites are generally wary of seeking out restaurants in the mysterious boroughs, or at least those establishments they can't see from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; At Restaurants, From Neapolitan Dishes to Middle Eastern Delicacies

body: DANCE and theater in Brooklyn are a matter of institutions and adventures. The Brooklyn Academy of Music, an institution par excellence, celebrates its 125th anniversary this year. But there are vital younger institutions like the BACA Downtown Center for the Arts, now 20, and the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center, a 10-year-old mecca for black
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; A Bustling Scene On a Bevy of Stages

body: IN the heart of New York's most populous borough, Prospect Park and its verdant partner, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, wander over nearly 600 acres of meadows, woodlands, waterways and an array of theme gardens. Here in Brooklyn's great backyard are also historic houses and sculptures, a zoo and skating rink, a Japanese garden and a horticultural
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; Woodlands and Exotic Gardens

body: Art shows are not as easy to come by in this sprawling borough as in cosy, prodigal Manhattan. There is the glorious Brooklyn Museum, to be sure, but after that, what? No SoHo, no TriBeCa, no Madison Avenue - in short, no gallery ''scene.'' Yet Brooklyn actually has a lot to offer in the way of exhibitions, and part of the fun is seeking them out.
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; Art Shows in Familiar and Unexpected Places

title: METRO DATELINES; Complaints Lead To Drug Arrests

body: Long before the corruption scandal broke in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, Charles J. Hynes traveled to 73 station houses in nine months, encouraging police officers to report abuses and assuring them that they were not being singled out for attack. He was met, he said, with sullen faces. ''It was like pulling teeth to get them to talk,'' said Mr.
title: PROSECUTOR FINDS POLICE CASES HARD, BUT NEEDED

body: Subway riders and drivers who use the Manhattan Bridge face disruptions far beyond those first estimated. title: MANHATTAN BRIDGE'S PROBLEMS DRAG ON

body: Friday WOMEN AS EXPLORERS An exhibition focusing on the contributions made by female explorers opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, where it will be on view through April. title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: IN the 17 years since Congress passed the Federal Clean Air Act, officials in New York City and other congested metropolitan areas have learned that clean air does not come easily. Now, with a major deadline for reducing pollutants little more than a year away, the big cities are facing tough decisions about the movement of cars and trucks.
title: CLEAN AIR DEADLINE NEARS, AND CITY PONDERS ITS CHOICES

body: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing two men who were found decapitated on Tuesday in a Queens apartment, the police said. One victim was identified as Roger Berne, 63 years old, who lived in the first-floor apartment at 90-59 56th Avenue, in East Elmhurst, where the bodies were found. The other was Gerald
title: BROOKLYN MAN IS HELD IN KILLINGS

body: State investigators say a private mental-health program in Brooklyn has misused as much as $4 million in public funds, mainly through the payment of ''exorbitant'' rents to a real-estate corporation owned by the family of the program's founder and medical director. title: PSYCHIATRIC UNIT SAID TO MISUSE FUNDS

title: METRO DATELINES; Man Shoots 5 In Social Club

title: LATE NIGHTS, BRIGHT LIGHTS AND COCAINE ARE STILL ENTWINED

title: A PLAN FOR BROOKLYN RISES AT ATLANTIC TERMINAL

title: Give Central Brooklyn a Boost

body: AS of Sunday, it's officially autumn, which means that the peak season for New York street fairs and festivals is drawing rapidly to a close. title: A CORNUCOPIA OF CELEBRATIONS ALL AROUND TOWN

body: A gypsy-cab driver in Brooklyn, apparently angered by a fare dispute with his passengers, used his car as a ram yesterday and struck and injured nine people on the sidewalk outside the Kings County Hospital in Flatbush, the police said. The driver, identified as Herode Magloire, then jumped out of the cab and fled to the hospital grounds but was
title: ENRAGED CABBIE RUNS DOWN 9 NEAR A HOSPITAL

title: ABOUT NEW YORK; 101 Percent Brushless: A Car Wash Saga

body: Out of dusty attics, dank basements and cluttered closets, Brooklynites are spinning the web of their history. title: CLUTTERED ATTICS HOLD BITS OF HISTORY FOR MUSEUM DEDICATED TO BROOKLYN

body: Housing The oldest building in New York City is a Dutch Colonial farmhouse built in or about 1652 and still as far off the beaten path for most people as it was when it was in the distant Brooklyn farm country of East Flatbush. title: STUDENT SEIZED IN SHOOTOUT GOT CARE IN GEORGIA

body: Congregation Chizuk Hadas in Flatbush is situated in a long narrow room that was once the ground-floor apartment of a two-family house. title: SMALL JEWISH CONGREGATIONS ATTRACTING MORE WORSHIPERS

title: CLERK IS KILLED IN TOKEN BOOTH AT IRT STATION

title: A Teen-Ager Is Killed In Brooklyn Shooting

body: Out on the asphalt, where young men dream of what Len Bias had, there was little illusion. That the basketball star's cocaine-related death was tragic, all agreed. title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

title: Random Shooting in a Store Wounds Brooklyn Teen-Ager

body: The last red-and-black truck pulled away from the Ebinger Baking Company's plant in Flatbush on Aug. 27, 1972, leaving thousands of red-eyed customers bereft of blackout cakes and pecan coffee rings. title: N.R.A. JOINS CORE IN DRIVE

title: TWO JEWELERS SAY GUNMEN SEIZED THEM AND $1 MILLION

title: CAMPAIGN GIFTS TO SENATOR TIED TO CREDIT UNION

title: JAY TUROFF: A CLASSIC SUCCESS STORY LEADS TO DUAL PORTRAIT OF EX-TAXI CHIEF

body: PULL the curtains aside and open the window. It isn't snowing. In fact, the sun is out and a breeze stirs the branches of the tree below, whose spindly shoots seemed so overly optimistic not very long ago. Spring has arrived at last. Now is the time to explore the streets, parks and waterfronts of the city, before the enervating heat of summer
title: EXPLORING THE GREAT OUTDOORS: WALKING TOURS, STREET CELEBRATIONS AND A BUTTERFLY SAFARI

body: THE secret gardens of Boston's Beacon Hill, interiors of homes in Philadelphia's Society Hill, avant-garde town houses in Manhattan and mansions along Embassy Row in Washington will all be open to curious eyes this month and next. These are the important months for house and garden tours and decorator show houses along the Eastern Seaboard. Many of
title: NOW IS THE TIME TO TOUR HOMES

body: WBAI Spring Crafts Showcase, Ferris Booth Hall, Columbia University, 115th Street at Broadway; 212-695-4465. Woodworking, blown glass, basketry, quilts, tapestries and special handcrafted pieces such as fiber wearables will be offered tomorrow through Sunday. Tomorrow 5-9 P.M.; Saturday noon-8 P.M.; Sunday noon-6 P.M. Admission $4 ($2 for elderly
title: EVENTS; CRAFTS, FLOWERS

body: GRAVE CIRCUMSTANCES Since it opened in 1838, the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn has been the place in which famous New Yorkers have found their final address, while living ones enjoyed just strolling through the beautiful setting. As Henry J. Raymond, a founder of The New York Times (and who is interred in Green-Wood), wrote in 1866, New Yorkers
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: The New Theater of Brooklyn is presenting ''Waiting for the Parade,'' a Canadian work that explores the experiences of five women during World War II, waiting at home for their husbands, sons, fathers and lovers to return. Melanie Joseph directed the John Murrell play. ''Waiting for the Parade'' will run through May 18 at the New Theater of
title: Canadian Play At Brooklyn Theater

body: A sculpture exhibition with an angelic theme is opening tomorrow at the Grand Army Plaza Arch in Brooklyn. The show in the arch's interiors, ''Wings Over Brooklyn,'' features works by Joel Carreiro, Deborah Masters, Linda Peer, Jorge Rodriguez and Ned Small. Crowning this spring's exhibition are the permanent turn-of-the-century winged figures by
title: High-Flying Sculpture At Grand Army Plaza

body: TO THE LIVING SECTION: While your story on Caribbean cuisine in New York does mention the fact that Brooklyn has a large Caribbean community, you go on to discuss the trendy places in Manhattan [ ''New York Embraces Island Fare,'' April 9 ] . Next time try coming to the source! Call up a diner on Flatbush Avenue and ask about their specials. They
title: The Caribbean Source

body: FROM LITTLE ACORNS The Chelsea Theater Center lives. Founded in 1965, the center oversaw more than 150 productions that won many awards, including five Tony Awards. After its beginning in St. Peter's Church on West 20th Street, the center moved to the Church of Holy Apostles. It operated out of the Brooklyn Academy of Music for nine years,
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: The Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Lukas Foss, will play a program of music by Pierre Boulez, Gyorgy Kurtag, Robert Saxton, Per Norgaard and Poul Ruders at Cooper Union tonight at 8, repeating the program tomorrow night at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Tickets are $7.50. Cooper Union is at Third Avenue and
title: Brooklyn Philharmonic

body: A Brooklyn woman died last night hours after an Emergency Medical Services ambulance crew that was summoned to aid her at her sister's home left without taking her to a hospital, the police said. The police said the ambulance crew told them that the woman, Beverly Stevens, 38 years old, had ''refused to go and became abusive.'' But a friend of Mrs.
title: WOMAN DIES HOURS AFTER AN AMBULANCE DEPARTS FROM SCENE

body: A LITTLE WATER, PLEASE Venturesome New Yorkers love to explore ethnic restaurants, including those of China, India, Thailand and the Philippines. To somewhat chart the course of the kinds of food available, the New York Public Library is sponsoring a short series of Tuesday talks, ''The Spices of Life: Spices and Food of the Orient.'' The second
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: This morning at 7:30, Philip Goldstein is to raise the flag in Joyce Kilmer Square, at Kings Highway and East 12th Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. At sundown, he is to lower it and take it home. Thus, Philip will begin his term as custodian of the flag, a job he volunteered for last January. ''When the space shuttle blew up,'' Philip, a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Volunteer Flag-Raiser

body: Downtown Brooklyn has for decades dreamed of a Manhattan-style office rejuvenation. Recently, with several large developers announcing plans for more than 2.5 million square feet of office and residential space, borough leaders saw those hopes start to come to fruition. Now, in another sign of the downtown area's growing economic health, some of
title: POSTINGS; Brooklyn Revival

body: A 22-year-old Bronx man, arrested this month on charges of raping and knifing a Brooklyn College student, was charged yesterday with three more rapes and a sexual assault, the police said. The suspect, Derrick Hamilton, of 2188 Strang Avenue, has been held in the Brooklyn House of Detention since his arrest March 12 in the rape of the college
title: THE CITY; RAPE SUSPECT HELD IN OTHER ASSAULTS

body: Two women have been charged with stabbing a man and woman to death in an argument after a party in the couple's Brooklyn apartment last week, the police said yesterday. The suspects were arrested Tuesday evening and charged with second-degree murder in the deaths of James Smith, 66 years old, and Lillian Paul, 55, in the apartment they shared at
title: Two Women Charged In Slaying of a Couple

body: Irish New Yorkers of every nationality turned 40 blocks of Fifth Avenue into a bobbing green sea of bagpipes and balloons yesterday as they swept up the street in the city's 224th annual St. Patrick's Day parade. More than 150,000 marchers, including Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and more than 100 bands from Long Island to Limerick, Ireland, followed
title: 150,000 MARCH FOR ST. PATRICK IN THE 224TH PARADE

body: An increase in complaints from students about the recruiting practices of private business schools has led state education officials and lawmakers to closely examine the rapidly growing business-school industry and the way it enrolls students. ''There has been a great proliferation of both recruiters and schools,'' said Peter D. Riley, chief of the
title: NEW YORK SCRUTINIZING BUSINESS SCHOOL AGENTS

body: A 22-year-old Bronx man has been charged with raping and stabbing a woman Monday in a Brooklyn College classroom building. He was also charged with two recent sexual assaults near the campus. The suspect, Derrick Hamilton of 2188 Strang Avenue, was arrested Wednesday night at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, where he was attending a course to become an
title: Bronx Man Is Charged With Rape at a College

body: Friday 'COUNTESS' IN BROOKLYN The New Theater of Brooklyn opened a new production in its new home this week with ''Countess Mitzi,'' a portrait of love in turn-of-the-century Vienna by the Austrian playwright Arthur Schnitzler. Cynthia Lammel stars as Countess Mitzi, with Neal Randell as the Count and David Reinhardsen as the Prince. Weekend
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Moments after he had won the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title from Marvin Johnson in 1980, Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, surrounded by his supporters, flashed back to a similar scene years earlier. One night in 1971, when he was still known as Eddie Gregory, he made the trip from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn to Madison Square
title: BOXERS LOOK AT GOLDEN GLOVES AS FIRST ROUND TO GREATNESS

body: Ben Vereen recalls accompanying his mother to her cleaning job at Loews Kings Theater - Brooklynites pronounce that ''LOW-ees'' - and dancing on the huge stage while she worked. Barbra Streisand was an usher at the mammoth theater. And if you believe Anita Pfleiderer, who works in a school office, most of Nassau County grew up, as she did, in the
title: RESCUING THE LOEWS IN FLATBUSH

body: It was a marriage of romance and real estate, Aphrodite and apartments. The room was New York City's marriage license bureau, where conversations about wedding rings, caterers and invitations mingled with talk of down payments, finder's fees and 3 Rms. w/EIK. They were all young, all in love. And somewhere in the process of courting, getting
title: NEWLYWEDS' APARTMENT HUNT: A TRYING START FOR A NEW LIFE

body: AS THE TWIG IS BENT Four Irish-American women fiddlers who were bowing away by the time they reached the age of 12, continuing a family tradition, will be featured in a concert of Irish-American fiddle styles, today and tomorrow at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. They will be joined by a fifth woman, a specialist in French Canadian fiddle playing. The
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: A plastic surgeon was indicted yesterday on charges that he raped a patient after placing her under sedation. The surgeon, Dr. Byron Major Jr., 45 years old, who lives in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and practices at 1000 Park Avenue, was charged with one count of first-degree rape and one count of first-degree sexual assault. He faces up to 25
title: THE CITY; Surgeon Accused Of Raping Patient

body: An assistant principal at a Brooklyn junior high school said yesterday that her supervisor had solicited $6,000 in loans from her while she was seeking a promotion. She said the supervisor had later refused to return the money, telling her that it should be considered a campaign contribution to his father, a member of the local school board.
title: TEACHER GIVEN A PROMOTION SAYS SHE GAVE CHIEF A LOAN

body: Finding a decent, affordable rent-regulated apartment in New York is like trying to recover a contact lens from a subway platform at rush hour. It can be done, but it takes dogged determination and a lot of luck. Statistically, the frustration is suggested by the city's unoffical vacancy rate of minus 1 percent -- the official rate of 2 percent of
title: THE ELUSIVE RENT-REGULATED APARTMENTS

body: A FEW months ago I attended the wake of my cousin. It might as well have been yesterday, because the image of him in repose preys on my mind as if it had been my own brother's. ''There but for the grace of God go we,'' my brother and I said to each other as we drove up and down the avenues of our former Brooklyn neighborhood, keeping one eye out
title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; THE LIFE THAT WAS AND THE LIFE THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN

body: ''I'VE had to look for an apartment five times in five years and it's been terrible every time,'' said Elizabeth Pearson, a production editor at Random House, the New York publisher. An affordable apartment in New York City sounds like an impossible dream, but every day hundreds of people find regulated apartments with below-market rents. Some have
title: TALES OF APARTMENT-HUNTING: HOW SOME SUCCEEDED

body: At least 40 members of New York City's community school boards have failed to pay thousands of dollars in outstanding parking tickets, including two who owe more than $11,000 each, an examination of city records shows. Leading the list of the 40 local board officials is Sylvester Leaks, a member of Community School Board 17 in Brooklyn and the
title: 2 ON LOCAL SCHOOL BOARDS OWE CITY $11,000 IN FINES

body: TO buy Brooklyn from the Indians, the early Dutch settlers paid 200 times as much they did for Manhattan, a new analysis of 17th century records shows. In part, this is because the native residents had become more savvy about the value of land. But the pattern of land transfers in Brooklyn, which was sold bit by bit in 22 different deals, was also
title: EARLY RECORDS SHATTER IMAGE OF INDIANS AS DUPES

body: USING SPARE TIME What do performers do in their spare time offstage? In the case of the company of the recent musical ''Poppie Nongena,'' the answer is: they perform. During the show's tour after its Broadway run, the cast spent its leisure hours on the road putting together a revue, ''Halala,'' that starts performances tonight at the Douglas
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: She had inadvertently misdialed, so instead of the number she had intended to reach, Clara Greenspan got a recording recited by an unfamiliar youngster's voice. The girl sounded as if she were about 6 or 7 years old, and this was her message: ''Hi, this is Elissa. I'm being punished so I can't come to the phone, but please leave a message when you
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: IN distance, it is four miles from Sackett Street in the lower Park Slope section of Brooklyn to Dorchester Road in Flatbush. But in housing terms they are not so distant, for vacant older buildings are undergoing rehabilitation into condominiums in each location. The prices to buyers vary sharply, however, a reflection mainly of the variation in
title: PERSPECTIVES: BROOKLYN HOUSING; VACANT BUILDINGS BEING REVIVED AS CONDOMINIUMS

body: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was born 57 years ago this week, is only the second American to have a Federal holiday named for him: Americans celebrate George Washington's birthday in February, but a proposal in 1920 to make Abraham Lincoln's birthday a national holiday failed to come to a vote in Congress. The nation this year, for the
title: IN MUSIC, READINGS AND FILM, SALUTES TO DR. KING

body: F. MURRAY ABRAHAM, who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the composer Antonio Salieri, the envious adversary of Mozart, writes: Brooklyn is alive and well. While shopping with my wife at Flatbush and Avenue U, I asked my salesman for use of the toilet. He needed clearance from his boss, who shouted: ''Hey, you guys, you know who this is?
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: The morning after was much the same as the night before: one of the most quiet and restrained New Year's holiday celebrations in recent years. On the observation deck of the Empire State Building, Kiyoyuki Kikutake from Japan and his wife and young son were gazing out over New York City. He was there, he explained, to find an equivalent to the
title: NEW YEAR IS GREETED WITH RESTRAINT AND NEW TRANSIT FARE WITH DISTRESS; ARRESTS AND DEBRIS DECLINE

body: Many New York hospitals lack the kinds of security forces that might have prevented the fatal shooting of a doctor at Kings County Hospital Center Monday, according to interviews with hospital personnel. Officials said that easily accessible, sprawling medical centers, coupled with an increasingly volatile mix of patients, make security an
title: AFTER SLAYING, HOSPITALS SAY SECURITY IS A GROWING WORRY
